p: Devi et al. carried out the anti-bacterial activity of methanol, ethanol and aqueous extract of the leaves of C. hirsutus (a concentration of 25, 50, 75, 100 ÂµL) using clinical bacterial isolates such as Escherichia coli, Salmonella typhi, Micrococcus luteus, Staphylococcus aureus, Acetobacter laffi, Proteus mirabilis and Bacillus cereus and the extracts showed potent antibacterial activities [ 51]. Nayak and Singhai carried out the anti-bacterial activity evaluation of the different extracts of roots of C. hirsutus against Staphlococcus aureus, Escherchia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Salmonella typhi and the ethanol extract showed potent antibacterial activity [ 52].
